Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Timing of Surgery Post-Chemoradiotherapy in Locally Advanced Rectal Cancer

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients with LARC within 12 cm of the anal verge (T3–T4 or N+ disease) were randomised using an adaptive biased coin technique

Participants.evidence: Patients with LARC within 12 cm of the anal verge (T3–T4 or N+ disease)

Intervention.evidence: undergoing total mesorectal excision (TME) after a waiting interval of 8 weeks or less (classic interval; CI) versus more than 8 weeks (long interval; LI) following preoperative CRT

Objective.evidence: This trial assessed disease recurrence and survival rates between patients undergoing total mesorectal excision (TME) after a waiting interval of 8 weeks or less (classic interval; CI) versus more than 8 weeks (long interval; LI) following preoperative CRT.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pathological complete response (pCR) rate, measured at the time of surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients with LARC within 12 cm of the anal verge (T3–T4 or N+ disease) were randomised using an adaptive biased coin technique to undergo TME within or after 8 weeks post-CRT. Randomisation was performed by two surgeons, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Pathologists assessing outcomes were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between January 2006 and January 2017, 350 patients were randomised (175 to each group).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of these, 322 were analysed (CI, 159; LI, 163) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The cumulative incidence of distant metastasis at 5 years was 30.8% in the CI group and 18.6% in the LI group (sub-HR = 1.78; 95% CI 1.14 to 2.78, P = 0.010).
